Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2012 11:40AM kane744 wrote: Timbuktu: Since this is my second round of chemo, separated by four years, I can tell you that for me chemo brain lightened but I still tend to blame it for all my memory issues which my friends and I share now that we're in our 60s.  Someone already answered your question about new primary, which is what happened to me.  First time in my right breast, had lumpectomy, chemo, and rads. Am triple negative, so couldn't do any of the five year stuff.  Four years later, during annual mammogram, tumor was found in left breast.  I decided our love affair was over and had a BMX with no recon.  Don't regret that decision. This time through chemo has been horrendous. Seriously want to just quit and take my chances since I played everything by the books and got a new cancer anyway.  But my onc says this is to prevent mets.  Right now I think this is too much to deal with. First time, though, my sister came to help.  One day I had a meltdown over a dirty kitchen.  I am a very clean person. Both my husband and my sister thought I might need to see a therapist so I called one and went the next day.  Know what she said? First, that it was the drugs making me act crazy and if my family didn't understand that then perhaps THEY should be seeing the therapist. Secondly, she told me to be very specific about what help I need.  I brought that to this treatment as well.  It's the poisons going through my system that makes me grouchy and depressed.  Plus, being sick day after day after day without let up is depressing.  I need things to control my se not anti-depressants.  Have been hospitalized twice in two treatments. I am sick, not depessed in the clinical sense.  So, give yourself a break.  Explain this to your family.   To help with chemo brain this time, I play word games on my iphone every day.  Last time I couldn't concentrate to read anything.  This time I'm reading book after book which is such a relief. I feel like shit but am hoping to muddle through.  Here's hoping you can do the same!
Posts.Title: Landed in hospital after 2nd treatment kane744 KeepingFaith69

Posts.Content: kane744 wrote: First posted back in July that I was starting chemo for my 2nd new primary bc on 8-1.  First treatment (taxotere/cytoxan) was pretty difficult and had to go to ER to have bad case of hives treated. That was the last night of the Olympics. Hair went pretty quickly. My 2nd treatment was on 8-23. My onc eliminated neulasta from the mix since that was the only thing different from the chemo 4 yrs ago. About a week out, had just about every se there is!! Next my fever spiked to 103 and I had no energy whatsoever. Yep, the hives came back but I had all the stuff to treat at home. Anyway, it was Labor Day weekend of course and on Mon. couldn't hold out any more and went back to ER. All my counts were way way down and was admitted. Massive doses of antibiotics, to units of blood, and three days later I was permitted to come home. My onc said once the hives came back, she new it was an allergic reaction to taxotere and I couldn't take it any longer. Now she wants to replace it with andriamycin for my 3rd treatment on the 12th. I refused the muga test cause they couldn't use my port and I can't be stuck due to le so had an echo instead. While home have read what I can about this "new" drug and have to admit I am scared of it. Well, actually, am scared of the 3rd chemo period! Don't want to end up so sick again and back in hospital. I am tempted to quit and my onc and I discussed this and she urges me forward because I'm TN as well and she wants to give me that weapon against mats. Plus my dh would be devastated if I quit. But. I haven't had a day that I felt ok again and this is supposed to be my good time before next treatment. I don't even know what I'm asking here. Chemo brain has hit big time! Oh yeah. Anyone have allergic reaction to taxotere? Anyone on adriamycin and your experiences with it? Anyone want to quit and did? Did it make a difference? Any words of encouragement? I am down down and nearly defeated. I feel like my body is quitting on me and I don't know what to do. I still have se from the 2nd treatment and no energy. Both times the bc caught early but this time had bmx. And this time chemo is so so much worse even though my attitude going in was pretty good and positive. Am I letting myself down? Don't know.  Dx 9/26/2008, IDC, <1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 0/14 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Dx 5/2012, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, 0/1 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Surgery 6/26/2012 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left; Prophylactic mastectomy: Right Chemotherapy 8/1/2012 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2010 05:49PM kane744 wrote: Well, Cori, I'm sure you're not excited to become a member of this club, but you have certainly landed in the perfect spot to get educated and meet a bunch of other women in the same boat.  I can't answer your technical questions since I'm a relative newbie myself, having been diagnosed four months ago.  I can only share my experiences.   At the beginning of my treatment, I stayed in bandages for three weeks, 23/7 (allowed an hour a day for showering, massaging, etc.).  My husband accompanied me to all LE therapy visits because I have it in my dominant arm and would have had trouble managing the wrapping myself.  He's quite the expert and I have learned how to do it as well, though it doesn't look as nice.  After the three weeks, my swelling was down significantly and I was measured for a sleeve and gauntlet which I wear every day without fail.  I was lucky enough (if you can refer to it as lucky) to be able to wear a ready-made sleeve.  The first one was perfect.  I ordered two of each, but now have five cause I got sick of washing them all the time.  At first, after taking off the sleeve/gauntlet, I had to wrap for the night.  Now, I only have to do so if I'm having a flare.  This summer has been pretty rough for many of us le gals and I have flared quite a bit due to the tremendous heat and humidity.  But I know what to do now and am able to pretty much self manage successfully.  My latest flare was giving me trouble, but one day this week we had a glorious low-80s, no humidity break and my arm went down just like that, so that took a weight off my mind.  This has significantly changed my life and I had a lot of emotional turmoil in the beginning.  Thankfully, I found this site and have received a wealth of information, encouragement, support, and friendship from my sisters here.  There's a lot to learn, believe me, but as everyone told me, it does get better once you learn how to self manage. There's a website called Step Up-Speak Out, which is an invaluable source of information.  I suggest that if you haven't visited it yet, do so as soon as you can.  You will find answers to many of your questions.  There are several women here who are absolute experts on many aspects of le and I'm sure they will be responding soon.  Honestly, these women give so much of themselves to help us.  I don't know what I'd have done without them. One thing I have learned is that le reacts differently for different women.  So once you get yourself "unswelled", learn how to massage, do the exercises, wrap, etc., etc., etc. you will be able to experiment on what works for you and what doesn't.  For me, I learned I have to wear my compression garments every day all day or I swell.  I have to massage twice a day or I swell.  I had to cut way way back on things like gardening and being outside in general during the hottest parts of the day or I swell.  Like I said, it's a learning process. I hope this helps a little bit but as I said, it's from my perspective.  Yours may be different.  Just know that we are all here to support you as best we can.

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2012 09:15AM kane744 wrote: My BMX was June 26. The last couple weeks before surgery, I was constantly soothing my breasts, almost comforting them, for what was to come. To the outside world I put on a brave front, but when alone, there were tears. It's not that they were such pretty things. After all, I'm 68 with all that that implies breast-wise, Plus four years ago, I'd had a lumpectomy with chemo and rads, so there were ugly scars. Still, they were MY boobs and had been with me all my life.  The morning after surgery a resident I'd never seen before popped in to check on me. Some young guy with plenty of knowledge but totally lacking in life experiences. He caught me when I was silently crying with tears rolling down my cheeks, snotty nose. One of those ugly cries. He says to me, not unkindly, "You know, this is the second time I've seen you and both times you've been crying. I want you to know you don't have to feel this way. What say we put you on antidepressants and make you feel happier." My dander rose. "Look," I said to him, "my breasts that I've had all my life were just amputated and I think it's a perfectly natural, normal thing to mourn their loss, especially the morning after. What if you had your penis cut off? How would you feel?" A nurse who was standing there put her hand over her mouth to hide her smile. And when he left the room, she patted me and said I did good. Today it's three weeks. Emotionally I'm much better but occasionally I have my moments. That's mostly due to the dread of treatment to come. I am pleased that my surgeon listened to me when I told him I wouldn't ever want recon. He gave me what I asked for and I am grateful. I can see that it will heal in a most acceptable way to me and my dh. It's something we both can live with for sure. So don't be afraid to feel your emotions. It's not wrong; it's the way you feel and it's a natural and normal reaction.
Posts.Title: Mourning my breasts pre-mastectomy...A eulogy NanG crystalphm

Posts.Content: kane744 wrote: Sorry I haven't posted for awhile. After the beginning of chemo on 8-1, was sick as a dog. I actually forgot how awful that first week can be. Still, was better than the last time. I wasn't bedridden. I could read. The Olympics kept me occupied when I had to zone out. All in all my personal triumph. Saturday was my best day and coincided with a break in weather, in the 70s and no humidity. I sat on the deck for several hours enjoying the gardens and stayed out of the sun. Sunday, the shit hit the fan. Woke up with me scalp on fire and my fingernails raking through the itches. My palms were on fire and itchy. Then uder my arms, then groin. By 10:30 pm we were off to the ER, me thinking this can't be cellulitis. It wasn't. Hives. It was the 11th day after chemo so it wasn't reaction to that. DH and I went over everything I used, ate, did and couldn't figure out what it the cause was. Anyway, the medical team mixed me up a nice drug cocktail, injected into my port and half hour later the itch was tolerable, the swelling in my hands down and it was sweet relief. They told me not to wear compression for a couple days. Another sweet relief. Took it easy, elevated, rested, MLD'd three times a day and came through OK. Today I felt I needed compression so donned my sleeve and gauntlet and will take off if need be. Myofacial is completely gone under left used to be breast, and releasing nicely on right, where previous radiation presented more of a challenge. Am still swollen and don't feel comfortable getting foobs yet. What's the rush, right? Hair started falling out in buckets yesterday and almost bald in front. Gonna get it all shaved off this afternoon. Got my "Hair by Chemo" hat ready. No wigs, no scarves for me. My biggest challenge is losing my anger over cancer coming back.  Intellectually, I realize I'm a lot better off than many women. Emotionally, it's a big "why me." But slowly, am gaining control over that crap. I do not miss my boobs. Not one bit. This surprises me, since I was so wrecked at the thought of having a BMX.  Am having a lot of nerve regeneration issues but discovered if I stand up, do some shoulder rolls and chest stretches, I get some relief. Sometimes, though, I can't stand to have clothing touch my skin and have to give in and sit here chest exposed.  I've been trying to think of a short term for "my chest formerly known as boobs." Any ideas anyone? Excuse any typos, chemo brain has set in. Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2010 08:03PM kane744 wrote: I must be really strange!  I found not having hair anywhere quite liberating.  Boy could I get ready to go out really fast!  At first I did the wig thing, then the hat thing, then the scarves.  Finally, I just said, "Screw this, it's not my fault I have cancer." and presented myself to the world bald.  I got treated really nicely, met many women who had gone through treatment or were getting ready to.  I also decided when it started growing in (about three weeks after chemo ended) that it was a good opportunity to stop coloring.  So now I'm, shall we say, pewter.  When my hair first got some length, it was curly curly curly.  Loved it.  Eventually that went away.  Now it's everything--some curly, some straight, some wavy.  Got so fed up with it (even though I said I'd never complain about bad hair days again) that I had it cut short short short.  And that's where I am today.  Life is about changes.

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2009 11:21AM kane744 wrote: I was told I wasn't a "good cancer patient" because I complained too much (I was blistering under my breast after only the fifth treatment)!!!   Believe me, I suffered a lot in silence before finally speaking up.  I've had cancer four times, four different kinds, and until this experience, mostly just kept my mouth shut.  This time I'm all grown up (old even) and I'm intent on sharing my problems with the techs, nurses, and doctors.  How else will they know?  And I too fired my surgeon for calling me neurotic after expressing my concern over a new lump I found not even a year after my first bc diagnosis.  I kept bringing it to his attention and he kept poo pooing it.  Fortunately, the cancer clinic where I go has levels of help patients can explore if they are not getting what they need.  I explored that option and they got me a mammogram, ultrasound and MRI immediately, along with a new surgeon if I need one.  The new one has a lot of compassion to go along with his skills.   I truly believe that reforming the health care system starts with us.  We must be our own advocates.

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2010 08:35AM kane744 wrote: Ohhh.  Another horse person!  First of all, I want to say this thing.  If you ride and have formed a partnership with your horse(s), you definitely have the art already for sweet confrontation!  Riding teaches a lot about life.  When to be nice.  When to be "firm".  And with a 1,200 pound animal.  Surely you are capable of handling a 150 pound doctor!  Just carry your crop in there for support. LOL. I kept my port in for over a year after treatment.  Have had poor veins for years and lots of follow-up contrast tests and the like.  The "last" thing on the schedule was a colonoscopy and I was advised to keep it for that.  It was months after the previous test, but I kept it.  When the day came, they couldn't use it cause I hadn't "brought my own needle" and they didn't have the proper one.  I was furious.  First, because I had called to explain all this; secondly, when they called to confirm the appt., I brought it up again and was assured it was in the chart so they'd have what they needed on hand and not to worry.  Oh, I was FIRM that day, let me tell you.  I told 'em I don't bring my own parts when I have my car fixed!   Anyway, because of temper tantrum (their description), they got me the BEST nurse who found a vein straight away.  After that, the port was removed, one year, three months after chemo stopped.  I don't miss it/I do miss it.   When I had that port removed was when I truly felt that my bc treatment was OVER.  At last. Felt good.  So if you feel better keeping it till after Dec., go for it. Glad you've joined us, but not for the reason, of course!

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2010 10:34AM kane744 wrote: Lymphetherapist:  I somewhat agree about your "overdo" theory.  However, if we are at all in tune with our bodies, we should know our limits.  For example, I jumped horses for years (I mean, I jumped over fences with horses).  There came a time in my life when I knew I was getting a bit long in the tooth for that sport, but didn't listen to my inner self, had a bad fall, eventually requiring surgery.  I wasn't too old to jump; I was too old to fall.  I knew that, but it was such a thrill!!  On the other hand, life DOES happen and sometimes le is part of that, I guess.  When I was diagnosed three months ago, I was confused because I had done exactly what my doctors told me to do or not to do.  Basically, they told me not to worry about it.  They didn't know and I felt like I was paying the price.  That's why I am so utterly grateful for people like you who can help us learn how to self manage.  I'm still learning all the time.  With this latest flare, I KNEW I should have wrapped because I overdid it, but was too tired and lazy.  A lesson learned the hard way.  My body requires me to do my le exercises and MLD twice a day and to wrap when I feel boggy.  I will listen.  Hopefully.
Posts.Title: Lymphedema Questions! TIA! lorieg Grayt

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2010 07:14AM kane744 wrote: Montrial, I was diagnosed almost three months ago and I learned a lot from all the women on this thread, but mostly from Binney and Kira, who are wonders.  When I was first diagnosed I felt completely helpless, hopeless, and totally freaked out!  Really, this was simply too much after breast cancer!  B & K guided me to the Step Up-Speak Out website, which was a huge help in educating me.  There are answers to practically every question you might have.  Plus, I rely on this thread a lot.  I made friends here and you will, too.  We are here for one another and you don't have to hold anything back. I, too, went to an le therapist, but am also lucky to have an le doctor.  Both are wonderful.  The therapist provided massage and taught me how to do it, taught me to bandage (gave me two sets of bandages and I order additional items from Lymphedema Products.com),  and when my four weeks in bandages were up and my swelling under control, she measured me for the sleeve and gauntlet.  She recommended Juzo, which turned out to be perfect for me.  I started with two sleeves and two gauntlets.  Now I'm up to four sleeves and six gauntlets (the gauntlets tend to get dirty fast).   I figure if you have more and alternate them, they will last longer than six months, but mark them, which I forgot to do.  Oh well.  I also got a variety of sleeve coverings by Sassy Sleeves to provide the loudness my life needs.  I'm sure when the fall sleeve/gauntlet colors come out, I will order a few of those. It's a steep learning curve and at first lymphedema occupied all my thinking.  It seemed completely overwhelming and I was really depressed.  Binny and Kira told me it would get better and, by darned, they were right.  I decided early on that I would comply with my doctor's and therapist's instructions to the letter and I have lived up to that.  I do MLD and exercises twice a day, I wrap at night when something seems "off" to me, and I wear my sleeve and gauntlet all day, every day. Since this is a very individualized condition, once you become more confident, you can experiment with things a little.  I'm not quite there yet, but I sure would like to be able to go without a sleeve on special occasions.  I'm still finding my way as far as life adjustments. Except for once a month le massage, my regular therapy is completed.  I have had several flares which I was able to handle myself with the help of people here.  My confidence has grown by leaps and bounds and I'm feeling better and better about dealing with this.   We were dealt a hand of crap, to put it bluntly, but we can learn to manage it and take care of ourselves.   I hope this helped a little bit and that you will keep on posting and asking questions.  You will find strength, humor, tears, laughter and more here.

Posts.Content: kane744 wrote: Ever since my bc, I have loudly proclaimed that I didn't want to get involved with any of this "stuff."  Then my dh, along with two other men, formed a support group for spouses/partners/whatevers of women with bc and he kinda pushed me toward participating in these functions.  I went to my first last night.  I met soooo many wonderful people, including a few women with le who WERE wearing their garments.  It was a hot, steamy evening and we were complaining and laughing together and sort of hung out the rest of the night.  After the survivor dinner, many women came up to us with suspicions that they might have "it".  There are two physicians in our city specializing in le, plus we had names of several le therapists which we freely shared.  I saw great value in attending just on this aspect alone.  I can help other women! Then came the awarding of survivor medals.  I was in tears from that point on and really surprised at being so emotional.  I ran into women I'd met during treatment, my wonderful chemo nurse and several others involved in my care.  When we did the Survivors Walk around the track, my new le buddies and I walked with our sleeved arms and gloved hands held high--a relief for our discomfort but also a proclamation that we are not ashamed of our lifelong condition. At the end of the walk, there was my dh waiting to fold me in his arms and he was crying, too.  Gosh, it was a wonderful night and I'm so happy to be alive, even with this horrid le thing.   So if you haven't yet attended any of these functions, I urge you to do it.  You will feel really good and you will set an example to those afraid to get diagnosed or ashamed to wear their garments.    Dx 9/26/2008, IDC, <1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 0/14 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Dx 5/2012, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, 0/1 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Surgery 6/26/2012 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left; Prophylactic mastectomy: Right Chemotherapy 8/1/2012 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2010 08:37AM kane744 wrote: Today--in the 90s with high humidity.  Looked in paper this AM for someone to prune/weed.  Only 3 people listed.  The recession must be ending!  I will stay inside and do a bit of housework.  Read more of The Help, which is a fabulous book.  It's my dh's birthday week, so I've got to plan things for that.  He wanted to increase it to birthday month, but I refuse.  And Wed. is my first docent day so I've got to study my schtick.   KC Mama,IMO it's the humidity by far!  Used to live in Northern CA, where we had heat w/o humidity and I did fine.  But humidity gets me every time.  Funny.  I'm starting to talk to my dh about relocating.  Not from the area, which we love, but from a three story house to a one story.  He's befuddled about my bringing this up, since we've been working on this house for so long and finally nearing the end of it.  Well, that's what I get for marrying a boy toy!  Bet you're all wondering about THAT!  Kira, you got a mosquito suit, too?  Wonderful but sweaty like mad, not to mention the look.  Little kids run from me.  My dh would just as soon not acknowledge me.  But it's better than poison.  I do not have trouble with punctures while gardening.  First I have my gauntlet, then over that, heavy leather gloves, then over that my mosquito gloves.  By the time I'm done putting things on, I look like a little kid in a snowsuit.  A little alien kid in a snowsuit. Binney, our first dogs were Tibetan Terriers and in reading up on their history I learned that when people first brought them to Great Britain, they used their hair/fur to weave winter clothes during WWII.  It's so cool that you are spinning yours.  I will definitely look into the cooling vest.  Forgot about that.  Otter, when we first moved to KY, a woman I met told me to watch out lest I be "belled".  She described it as a polite way proper southern women have of insulting you.  They say something horrid but so sweetly that you have no idea until hours later that you were put down. MOTC-Don't run in the heat/humidity!  I have friends who run and they never look happy when doing it.

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2010 09:07PM kane744 wrote: Happy to meet you Estepp, but sad for such circumstances.  I was diagnosed in April and was quite a wreck for awhile.  Still am on occasion.  All I can say is that for me, though the learning curve was steep, I caught on quickly due to a great le therapist; plus I had my dh to help me.   When I finally went from all the time bandaging to sleeve/gauntlet during the day, then night time bandaging, it was such a relief.  Now I only have to do bandaging at night if I have a flare.  Or if I'm going to be doing something that may cause one.  Such freedom!  Most of all, though, discovering this site has done so much to educate me.  I thank Binney and Kira every day for their dedication and knowledge.

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 06:51PM kane744 wrote: This being my first LE summer (spring was spent in CLD, wraps, education, and totally freaking out), everything I've done from my previous "normal" outdoor summer life has brought on a flare.  So I have avoided EVERYTHING.  I am hoping as I adapt, this will change cause, much as I love reading, am getting bored with the entire SOA (sitting on ass) thing.  But, now that I'm a Chickley girl, I have been practicing my breathing.  With this last session, she told me to breathe in slowly, imagining that the breath is coming from my toes all the way up.  As I slowly exhale, I lightly press on my abdomen area, clearing the main lymphatic whatevers.  She saw my skeptical look and made me try it.  The third time was nothing short of miraculous.  I felt everything sort of let go and my entire arm released what I can only describe as sweat but she called something else.  I was stunned, but it made me sort of believe.  So tonight, when I've done my MLD, I will practice my breathing and letting it all go.  We'll see.   Ninja's question is interesting about rapid or slow changes.  When I overdo, it seems as if the change is gradual, sometimes not showing up till the next day.  But the other day (the nice, low humidity, mid-80s one) when I sat out on the deck UNDER the awning, I could almost see my arm swelling.  I beat it the heck inside the house. Suzy, this last flare I wrapped for a couple days straight, as you did.  It did the trick.  But I hate wrapping at night.  HATE IT (I found the faces!!).  My sleeve is on the way.  Am so anxious to know how it'll work.  If I can get it on myself.  I got the Jovi-Pak based on the refrigeration ability.   But, Binney, mostly when I flare I think it's cause of something I've done but maybe it isn't.  And, while I feel badly for you, I also find comfort that you panic when one comes on.  Cause in my book you really have it pretty much together with this LE thing and if it still gets to you, then I'm not too crazy and that makes me really really .  Now that I've found 'em, I'll try my best not to overdo.  Hey, maybe these faces cause flares.
Posts.Title: Flare care??? Binney4 SleeveNinja

Posts.Content: May 26, 2010 10:19AM kane744 wrote: I'm a newbie LE, diagnosed April Fool's Day!  Good one on me, huh!  Have it in breast, arm, hand.  My LE therapist taught me that at the first sign of swelling, to wrap.  I do MLD 2 x day, wear my sleeve/gauntlet during day, every day, and if there is sign of swelling, wrap at night from fingers all the way up.  That ususally takes care of any flares for me.  Last night I thought a flare was starting but decided to go w/o wrapping and do extra long MLD (all through The Good Wife).  This morning was back to my new normal.  Binney says the sleeve/gauntlet keeps you where you are, and wrapping reduces swelling.  I've found this to be true for me.

Posts.Content: May 23, 2010 12:23PM kane744 wrote: Missrwe, I so often refer to my latest cancer experience as being placed an assembly line and off I went from one treatment to the next, appt after appt, and all the medical staff wants is your smiling compliance, never questioning too much what was being done to my body or what may result in ensuing years.  Well, I'm not that type of person so I didn't fit in very well.  That's why I was once told I was "not a good cancer patient."  Well, TS, it's MY damned body.  But not all my cancer experiences were like this (this is my 4th-all different).  When we lived in San Francisco and I had my third cancer experience, I was part of Team Me.  I had met every doctor on my team before treatment started and I had regular meetings with my team throughout.  As cancer experiences go, it was great.  I knew exactly when, where, why, and how.  It made all the difference in my attitude.  And it was all still very efficient.  It was a particularly rough experience, involving lots of pain, but I was A Good Cancer Patient because I was treated with respect throughout.  Maybe it's become this way now because there are so many of us.

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2010 08:11PM kane744 wrote: Sara, I am one of those misinformed women who a couple months ago developed lymphedema.  Whenever I expressed any concerns about it as I journeyed through my breast cancer treatment, I was poo-pooed.  I was told by three doctors that it's been practically eradicated due to SNB; told to go on as normal just avoid BP, blood draws, cuts or burns in that arm (I did all that and more); told the further away I got from surgery, the less chance I had of getting it.  All of this medical "advice" given by professionals who seemed completely disinterested in the subject of this out-dated lymphedema thing.  Am I pissed?  You bet I am.  Do I feel mean-spirited?  Yep!  This is for life, baby, and it's NOT in the least pleasant.  It has changed everything.  Go on as normal they said.  Well, that ain't happening now.  Any time I try to do something I enjoyed from my previous life, I swell and it's a damned hardship getting myself back down.  Take care of a horse?  Can't do that.  Gardening?  Other than pulling a few weeds, I can't really dig into the earth any more or continue with my grand landscaping plans that I've been working on for seven years.  I swell.  My "famous" homemade candy to give as gifts?  Bake bread?  Can't do that stuff either.  So unless you are in this le world, where we unlucky ones battle daily, please spare us your uneducated opinions.  We've all heard enough of those, thank you very much.  And I don't even know who this LS person is.  It's just that, unfortunately for thousands of women who have had to learn the hard way, there's a lot of suffering caused by misinformed people giving bad advice.  Believe me, lymphedema is real and it can happen to you, too.

Posts.Content: kane744 wrote: Well, I had my appt with my radiology oncologist this AM.  While I was waiting to be called in, I sat across from this older woman who was obviously hiding her arm along the side of the chair.  Finally, she caught my eye and said, "I wish I could have had one of those."  I asked her what and she responded the things I was wearing on my arm and hand.  She had had her BMX over 20 years ago, she said, as she shyly pulled her arm from its hiding spot.  Bless her heart, her arm looked like an elephant's leg and her hand was so badly swollen that I'm sure she could use it very little.  I asked her if she had ever seen a lymphedema therapist.  She hadn't.  No one had even mentioned it to her years ago and now her drs say it's too late to do anything.  Sadly, I don't know enough to know if this is true but I just can't believe she wouldn't get some relief from lymphedema therapy and suggested she insist she see a therapist.  She said she couldn't tell the doctors what to do!  Yes you can, I told her.  Just take a deep breast and tell them that you want to see one.  They work for you!  I then was called into my appt.  I started in on my le speech and handed her the material from SU-SO which she took and put in my file.  She said that these days hardly anyone gets le because of SNB.  I responded that mine failed to work and they did an axillary dissection.  She starts paging through my file and mumbled something about it being unfortunate.  Then I got angry.  UNFORTUNATE!!!  I said I feel that my medical team let me down and the only reason I got to see an le therapist was because I refused to shut up about it and that I will not be quiet until all women faced with bc surgery get measured before surgery, see an le therapist prior to it, and if they end up with an axillary dissection, they automatically be scheduled for le therapy.  After all that she still said that only 6% of women get le.  I told her she was incorrect.  I asked her if the cancer clinic reported women who do get it.  No, they don't.  There's no place to report it.  Well, then where does she get her 6% figure?  She couldn't answer me.   Then she got angry.  She said isn't it a sad state of affairs that men get their Viagra and women still have to struggle with things they shouldn't have to deal with.  She said so many women think that in these days they are equal to men, but they certainly are far from that.  Whoa!  That blew me away.  I knew then that she got it and had just spouting the clinic's line.  I told her about that woman in the waiting room who was so obviously humiliated about her le and had never been offered any therapy after all this time.  Turns out, it wasn't her patient, but she said she'd see what she could do. She then began asking me questions about my therapy.  Did I feel it did any good (duh), did I feel comfortable self-managing, did I wear my sleeve and gauntlet every day or just for dr appts.             I dunno if I did much good at all.  But I do know that a journey of a thousand miles begins with one step and I feel I accomplished one tiny step today.  I believe my radiology oncologist will be more aware of the women in her care and be on the lookout for signs of le in her patients. My next step?  Tackling the clinic powers that be.  That's more than one step, however.  But I am going to do this.   Feel pretty good.  Dx 9/26/2008, IDC, <1cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 0/14 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Dx 5/2012, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, 0/1 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Surgery 6/26/2012 Lymph node removal: Left, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Left; Prophylactic mastectomy: Right Chemotherapy 8/1/2012 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Loud, Bold and Brassy kane744 Artemis

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2010 11:28PM kane744 wrote: Welcome, Dawn!  I read your post and started to cry because I know EXACTLY how you feel and as a newbie myself--LE diagnosed 4/1--I recalled how I had to wade my way through doubting and sometimes even belittling doctors who tried to tell me that LE was rare "these days."  But I kept at it until at last I was referred to a doctor specializing in it.  She led me to my le therapist and months of training and education to learn to manage this THING.  Well, all my pals here know my story well. Anyway, though I wear a sleeve and gauntlet rather than glove, the gauntlet, too, can become pretty disgusting PDQ.  I now keep a box of disposable gloves in a kitchen drawer.  In a very short time it became second nature to grab one and put it on when meal prepping and sometimes using it when eating a particularly messy something or other, like a nice juicy peach.  When I start to sweat, I take it off, pitch it, dry and lotion my hand and put another one on until I'm done.  I also got some extra gauntlets for those just-in-case times.  I keep one in my car, one in my purse, and one with all my LE stuff.   My dh was helpful from the get-go.  My LE is in my dominant arm and hand so I have a difficult time wrapping myself.  He learned before me but I was determined to conquer it.  I do fine with the fingers and up to my  elbow wrapping but once I get to the upper arm...well, let's just say that sometimes the tears and curse words fly!  Just ordered a nightsleeve so I can feel some sense of independence.  Despite all his support and loving help, he, too, thought it might not be too helpful for me to go on this site every day.  I explained it to him as best I could.  If he still feels that way, he keeps it to himself.  I understand that he wishes things could just be life before.  I think it's just now dawning on him that this is a forever thing and I have to learn to manage it physically AND mentally.  This is my go-to place for support, understanding, sympathy, education, and sometimes even fun. I'm glad you had the courage to fight through the crap and get the help you needed.  Aren't we strong women!!!
Posts.Title: Finally have an LE Therapist BoobsinaBox BoobsinaBox

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 09:13AM kane744 wrote: Hi y'all.  Been out of commission for a few days with a NASTY cold and horrid cough.  Still don't have my voice back, but I know I'm almost back.  Anyway, we're leaving this week for our trip to NC, which will have many altitude changes from flats to mountains to flats to.....will wear my garments, take my squeeze ball and prop pillows with me.  Gee, I HAVE to have my morning cup of coffee, but will carry plenty of water to keep hydrated.  Since we're leaving quite early in the AM, I plan to do my share of the driving first,  while I'm still in good shape.  We'll see how I do through the mountainous areas of WVA.  If I feel swelling, I'll stop at the WVA Arts Center for a stretch and perhaps a quick look around (don't laugh, Suzanne), then let my dh take over.  I got a special little carry case for my le stuff so I have it all in one easily accessible place.  Interesting side note.  Have been virtually bedridden for the past three days and didn't bandage or wear my garments plus I only massaged once instead of twice daily.  I have had only a tiny bit of swelling in the elbow area.  Since I'm up today, I will go back to my routine, but I was just wondering why this happened. Cynthia, when we were young, something similar happened to us. Had to leave CA for awhile and move back to PA to my family.  We missed CA so much that after a few months decided to take our chances and go back.  It was a different time then, not so crazy as now.  We always were grateful that family was there for us to help us back on our feet.  All the best to you.

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 04:24AM kane744 wrote: My dear southern le sisterbelle.  I am so so sorry you are having such a bad time.  I think we've had enough of this damned hot, humid weather.  We seem to flare together for I am having another, too.  This time, I'm not freaking or obsessing over it.  Anyone believe that???  Last night I asked dh to help me wrap.  By the time I was finished with everything getting ready for bed entails, he was sawing logs and I didn't have the heart to wake him.  I tried wrapping myself and got stuck on the upper arm, kept trying till I was in tears. Am calling my le dr. today for a prescription for a night sleeve.  I DID take an ativan (such a charming little helper), massaged again, propped my arm on two pillows and went to sleep.  This morning before I even got out of bed, I did MLD, got up and did my "ring test" and failed.  Now I'm in bandages on a 98 degree day, so no outside for this woman. What's this tomatoes are bad for le crap.  COME ON!!!  I just went out and picked 20 gorgeous red babies and I feel like sitting here and eating every one.  And eggplant too????  Cripes, I've been eating those two veggies all summer in every way imaginable.  Who determines these things?  Was it some kind of study involving 5 or 10 people or something?  I AM IGNORING THIS.  Enough is enough.  I AM 66 AND WILL EAT WHAT I WANT.  I've made a real effort to give up chocolate (for the most part), oysters, cut down significantly on meat. I don't knowingly use salt. Have reduced my portions to lose weight.  I refuse to sit around and eat like a rabbit for however many years I have left.  This is really upsetting.  Where's that dang nasty face. Well, I got on here cause I had to cancel out on my volunteering due to the heat/humidity and I'm swelled, if not like a watermelon (probably also bad for le), surely like a juicy brat (which surely IS bad for it).   So just how does it work that we're supposed to live our lives like nothing's wrong.  I really don't get it, because my life has significantly changed.  SIGNIFICANTLY.   Did y'all hear about the flight attendant who had had it with a nasty passenger,  pressed the emergency chute, grabbed two beers, and slid away to freedom?  I cheer him mightily.  My hero.   I wish I could make a significant statement like that.  OK, he did get arrested.
Posts.Title: Singing the "When is your arm going to get better?" Blues Suzybelle o2bhealthy

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2010 11:03AM kane744 wrote: Ah Faith.  At the risk of getting disowned here, I am not, let's see how to put this without offending too many, I am not a "person of faith."  Living in Kentucky, I have many friends praying for me.  I have learned to thank them and change the subject.  Pity me if you will, just don't try to convert me.  Anyway, I appreciate your dispair.  Last night my dh, who has been so very helpful, kind, loving, caring, etc., etc. said to me he just doesn't get it.  Why, when I stay in the air conditioning all day long, am I swelling.  Honestly, I felt really defeated.  I asked him if he felt that it might all be in my head.  He very quickly denied that, but I could tell by the tone that he was feeling that way.  THEN he said that it didn't look all that bad to him.  So I unwrapped and we compared arms.  "Oh," he said.  Do you see it now????  I told him I could understand that he wishes things were different, but no more so than me.  This morning he apologized but I've been kind of down all day because of it.  I guess it gets to those who love us, too. I know, let's have those talented among us write a Lymphedema Blues song.  We could work on the lyrics together and then those who can, can set it to music.  Wanna?   I'm tired of feeling trapped inside my house, not even being able to enjoy the deck.  It's quite a lovely house, but not when it's a prison.  I'm tired of worrying that I'm going to keep swelling till I burst.  I want summer to be over.  But then, I've never gone through a winter with this crap, and it could be just as bad.  But at least I'll be able to go outside.  Three days now I've cancelled my volunteering, a thing I enjoy tremendously.  Whenever someone calls to ask how I'm doing, I just say fine. But no I can't go to the State Fair, sorry I can't make it to the baseball game, nope, can't do the flea market with you and forget the farmer's market on Saturday.  Oh yeah, this is living.
Posts.Title: Singing the "When is your arm going to get better?" Blues Suzybelle o2bhealthy

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 01:46AM kane744 wrote: Coming here keeps me sane.  Keeps me from feeling so alone in this THING.  Keeps me from feeling even more  sorry for myself, knowing others are going through the same thing.  Why wouldn't I come here when it does so much good for my head!  But my dh wonders the same:  Is coming here making me worse.  My response, if I stop visiting this site, will the LE go away?  Well, will it????  No.  It's FOR LIFE.  I am probably 90-95% compliant.  My downfall is not wanting to wrap at night.  That's why I'm getting a night sleeve.  Yesterday was a gorgeous day, glorious breeze, mid-80s, low humidity.  I hadn't sat out on the deck enjoying the gardens all summer.  I had the awning out, grabbed my iced tea and out I went.  After 30 minutes I could feel my arm ballooning.  COME ON, you stupid thing.  So I went back in, went upstairs, did my MLD and wrapped.  This morning am not down much.  Am staying wrapped all day.   Inside all day.   House is clean, laundry done, leftovers for dinner.  Will sit with my pillows, elevating my arm and reading.  Sick of it, but not feeling so terribly alone cause of my "swell sisters." Love  you all.
Posts.Title: Singing the "When is your arm going to get better?" Blues Suzybelle o2bhealthy

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2010 12:09AM kane744 wrote: I tried the neti pot once or twice and it totally freaked me out.  I felt like I was drowning or something.  Obviously, I didn't get the hang of it.  BUT...I have allergies as well and can't take any of the usual allergy meds because of high blood pressure.  My doc prescribed Flonase and cut the dosage in half--one shot up each nostril in the morning.  After about a week, I felt so much better.  If my nose dries up or becomes stuffy (I live in Kentucky, after all), I use Little Noses.  Mine ain't so little, but those saline drops really do the trick.
Posts.Title: Flaring and allergies - help! Tina337 Tina337

Posts.Content: May 28, 2011 03:31PM kane744 wrote: Dear Outfield, So sorry you are having to go through this.  It's a challenge that's for sure.  Till Binney or Kira get to you, there's a site called Step Up Speak Out which contains so so much info, including answers to some of the questions you've asked.  I guess, for me, the first big hurdle was accepting the fact that this is for life.  I'm still dealing with that but not on the same level as in the beginning.   It's a steep learning curve, but it will come!

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2010 11:15AM kane744 wrote: No, Inspie, and I haven't been officially diagnosed with it now.  The opth is "following" me, wanting to get the pressure at different times of day and another test.  I go back in early Sept. which is right around the corner.  But that's what made me start thinking hmmmmmmm.  Cause my pressure was always great.  Now 4 1/2 months after being diagnosed with le, my eye pressure is high.  I realize I'm older now, but still...  Anyway, the doc who discovered this lymphatic eye system (for over 100 years they thought the eye didn't have one), Dr. Yeni Yucell, has won a big time award for his team's discovery.  Don't you just LOVE the internet!

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2010 07:01AM kane744 wrote: Couple a things I forgot to add about flares.  The only actual pain I have is in my breast, which the LE doc thinks is related to LE and the oncology radiologists thinks it's still hanging on from her particular brand of cure.  It is hurting today, which is probably from my LE massage yesterday.  We went through it extra as she was trying to teach me things.  Which leads me to last night.  Went to bed at my usual time, before my dh, so I could do my massage/deep breathing.  DH says he's coming with me.  Oh oh.  He was in bed before me and finally I join him, turn out the light, etc.  He says to turn it back on, he wants to see this.  Oh oh.  Well, of course, I was very self conscious and asked him just to turn over and go to sleep.  Turned out the light and started again, trying to breathe from my toes up, exhale slowly.  Soon he says (his back turned toward me, mind you), "This is making me hot."  Not tonight, dear, I'm trying to reach Nirvana.  "I'll show you Nirvana," says he.   Obviously, this is something I have to do ALONE! One more thing.  Recently I posted about the possibility of glaucoma being related to LE.  I asked my Chickley about it and she says Dr. Chickley did extensive research on it and to him there is definitely a connection, so she LE massaged my eyes to release some of the fluid build up.  I haven't learned to do it myself yet.  I also found online that they recently discovered that the eyes do, in fact, have a lymphatic system which could drastically change how glaucoma is treated.  Hmmm.  Printed it out to take to my opth. And that's all the info that I forgot to write last night.  Back to the extensive heat and humidity today.  Cripes.

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2010 06:03PM kane744 wrote: Well, I have a flare.  Not from vacation, mind you.  Tell me it's not from vacation!  I think I was scrubbing my sink with too much gusto yesterday and I did just a tiny bit of pruning in the heat.  Yes, I was properly attired.  I knew I should have wrapped last night but was too lazy.  At any rate, I am thinking of a night sleeve but in looking at them all, they seem mighty complicated and certainly cumbersome.  I looked at the video for this one and I think I could do it.  But my daytime sleeve and gauntlet are 30/40 even though I'm classified as moderate.   As soon as I got home from PT (therapist noticed I was a bit ballooned and went easy on me), I went straight upstairs  to give myself a longer than usual massage and wrapped up.  Sigh.  Moan.  Groan.  Yes, gals, I'm back.  But what I want to know is, do those of you who have night sleeves invest in them mainly because wrapping is so tedious?  My dh thinks wrapping is more cost effective and I should stick with that.  What say you?
